Over the course of the workshop, the facilitators worked with the participants to resolve any identified problems. Videotapes of the workshops were reviewed by the facilitators to create a report that will be used to integrate stakeholder feedback into Project Design; the results of the workshops are summarized below: Overall the surrounding communities have a positive perception of the Project activity because it provides employment opportunities to local people. Plantation workers expressed concern that the Project activity takes the necessary precautions to ensure the safety on the job. The Project’s strategy for ongoing communication with stakeholders and incorporation of feedback into Project Design is outlined in the document “Política Comunicación Conciliatoria”. email:_iaguirre@econegocios.com.gt_/_iaguirre@gao.com.gt_phone:_+_(502)_2279-9038 The project has established 1,433.36 hectares of rubber tree plantations on degraded and degrading lands while creating a model for sustainable competitiveness, unique of its kind. The rubber tree plantations also have significant climate benefits, such as sequestering an expected 3,900,439 t CO2-e over 42 years. In 2016 the community benefits document include 302 permanent jobs with legal benefits, training, and health benefits. The project complies with all local laws, has public consultations processes to inform local stakeholders about project activity, development and monitoring. Most workers receive specialized training for their specific tasks. This year project areas have a grievance process in use in order to better document community feedback. Although benefits vary depending on project area due to their proximity to local communities and access to resource project offered life insurance, some projects created investment groups to incentivize savings, donations were given to local schools and communities such as water tanks, gas to voluntary fire men, resource donations for infrastructure development, restoration of roads, supervised practices in administrative offices, authorized use of local rivers and springs, donations for local festivities, church remodelation, and donation of pipes for local sewage. The projects expects to have biodiversity benefits such as serving as a buffer zone and biological corridor for the natural forests and areas of High Conservation Value, avoided deforestation, sustainable management to reduce chemical inputs, positive impacts on the environment (such as degraded soil, restore water recharge and mitigate wind effects) given the change from pasture to natural rubber tree plantations, and the project will also have an aesthetic positive impact on the landscape.

contamination_of_water_sources Protected Areas; avoid_any_forest_cover_loss Representative samples of existing natural ecosystems should be protected or restored to their natural state, based on the identification of biologically key areas, consultation with environmental stakeholders, local government and scientific authorities. Initially areas are identified through satellite images that map out historic changes in the area. Biological monitoring evaluates areas of special interest or potentially significant in the project instances based on available literature, historical mapping and land use. If a key species or ecosystem is identified, it would qualify as a biological key area. During consultations with community members and other stakeholders (environmental stakeholders and local government officials) there is also an opportunity to define any areas of special interest. Ecosystems will be returned to their natural state by allowing the natural regeneration of the area.

Due to previous land use, mostly cattle grazing, soil composition is improved through afforestation. In addition, intercrops and maintenance of the land ensures improved soil composition and tree management reduces erosion. This can be verified in the field and has been recognized in stakeholder consultations.

target_mitigation_measure_implementation Protected Areas; col_2 Representative samples of existing natural ecosystems should be protected or restored to their natural state, based on the identification of biologically key areas, consultation with environmental stakeholders, local government and scientific authorities. Initially areas are identified through satellite images that map out historic changes in the area. Biological monitoring evaluates areas of special interest or potentially significant in the project instances based on available literature, historical mapping and land use. If a key species or ecosystem is identified, it would qualify as a biological key area. During consultations with community members and other stakeholders (environmental stakeholders and local government officials) there is also an opportunity to define any areas of special interest. Ecosystems will be returned to their natural state by allowing the natural regeneration of the area.; col_3 Representative samples of existing natural ecosystems are protected or restored to their natural state, based on the identification of biologically key areas, consultation with environmental stakeholders, local government and scientific authorities.

cl_id_cl_03_section_no._1.2_date:_30/06/2023 The Project Participants have references from different sources (maps that are not updated, specific studies carried out for the farms, field measurements not verified by precise instruments) about the area (size) of protection of natural forests and gallery forests. Given this, as a measure to avoid uncertainties, the Project Proponent required a mapping work with a specialist in Geographic Information Systems -GIS- (GPI Consulting Services) to determine the protection areas. A comparative analysis of information from the 2020 Land Use Map, generated by the Guatemalan Ministry of Agriculture -MAGA- and satellite images of 2023 with ESRI source, was made to determine the existing areas of natural forest and riparian forest, as accurately as possible. From this account, the table in Section 1.2 of the Monitoring Report, where the "Change in the number of hectares significantly better managed by the project for biodiversity conservation, measured against the without-project scenario" is declared, has referred to the annex where the maps that are the result of this study are presented as evidence, and where the reported area can be verified. With the precise results of this study, the initially reported number of hectares was unprecise; therefore, data number was corrected in the Monitoring Report.

natural_risk a; col_2 Fire (F); col_3 0.0; col_4 Project Proponent conservatively has assessed significance for fire risk as “Insignificant (less than 5% loss of carbon stocks) or transient (full recovery of lost carbon stocks expected within 10 years of any event)”. This is reasonably given rubber plantation is an intensive crop and any unexpected loss would be immediately recovered by new plantations next rainy season and become transient. Natural regeneration is not an option to recover rubber plantations. In the evidence provided for information available at municipal level (more accurate) for a period of 12 years (1987 to 1999), no forest fires were reported in the municipalities where project sites exist. Evidence from 2000- 2015 demonstrated that the departments in which project sites do exist, less than 1% of total forest land has been affected by forest fires in Guatemala in those years. Project sites are not within the departments with most forest fires. Additionally, the most frequent causes of; col_5 The VVB reviewed that the selected information sources (INAB- amount of fires and affected areas, covering the seasons from 2000 to 2020)/3/ are from official sources and the information. biodiversity_element Justification of Change; connectivity The remnants of natural broadleaf forest, riparian forest and other ecosystems that currently exist in the projects as critical habitats that provide ecosystem services and "stepping stones" for the fauna and flora of the region, contributing to the connectivity of the farms with the forests surrounding remnants. ris_k_fac_tor a); risk_factor_and/or_mitigation_description Without legal agreement or requirement to continue the management practice; risk_ratin_g -24- (proj ect long evity /5); pp_justification Project longevity for the Project is estimated as equal to crediting period: 42 years. The entire Project longevity is dully covered by management and financial plans6. Replanting the Project sites is stated in the PD, Section 1.9.6, Rubber and timber harvesting: “Rubber will be extracted from trees starting in year six continuing for a minimum of 30 years following plantation establishment. At the end of their productive life span, the trees will be harvested for timber and the plantation will be replanted as stated in the Management Plans”. In addition, in the evaluation of Risk factor applicable to ARR projects, Section 1.11, the risk rating for Long-term commitment with harvesting was defined as Medium, in where Project Proponent again states the intention to replant. Despite the evidence for replanting, the Project Proponent has no legal agreement or requirement as AFOLU Non-Permanence Risk requires. Given this, the calculation for Project Longevity was assessed accordingly with factor a), as follow: Project Longevity = 24 – (project longevity/5); for the Project: 24 – (42 / 5) = 15.6; vvb_conclusion The VVB reviewed the longevity calculation is done as per NPR TOOL. No change versus previous version of the NPR is required. Correct. Calculated as per tool
